awd_titl_txt: Increasing Underrepresented Minorities in STEM: The 49th NOBCChE Annual Conference  National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the participation of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows at the national annual meeting for the National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) conference in 2022. This award is funded by Division of Chemistry. The NOBCChE meeting has become an important conference to recruit diverse global leaders in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields and to create an inclusive environment in the broader scientific community. This conference will be held in person in 2022, for the first time since the COVID pandemic began.  The PIs will use this as an opportunity to compare student outcomes between live and virtual conferences, providing insight that would be impactful to many other scientists and educators in STEM fields.

This award will provide opportunities for participants to engage in four major areas of focus: (1) STEM Professional and Technical Development, (2) STEM Mentoring and Networking Opportunities, (3) Exposure to Prestigious Minority Models in STEM, and Academic and Professional STEM Career Advancement Opportunities, and (4) access to potential careers in the STEM workforce. Student participants will interact with peers and professionals from industry, government, and academia to develop collaborations and to explore opportunities to pursue graduate degrees in the chemistry, chemical engineering and related disciplines. NOBCChE 2022 will also serve to enrich the technical, professional, and leadership skill sets of student attendees and students working on committees with other senior leaders on conference planning and execution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The 49th Annual National Organization of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) Conference was virtually from September 26 – 29, 2022. The conference theme was " Global Science Awakening: Celebrating Creativity and Innovation” which focused on cultivating conversations surrounding the advancement of science and students pursuing STEM careers. The conference had approximately 685 attendees, consisting of 365 students (126 undergraduate, 229 graduate, and 10 postdoc students) supported by the National Science Foundation. These students participated in professional development sessions and presented 247 technical posters and 93 oral presentations covering areas of chemistry and chemical engineering. The students represented public and private universities inclusive of historically black colleges and universities, predominantly white universities, and other minority-serving institutions.

Students attending the conference participated in four major areas: 1) STEM Professional and Technical Development; 2) STEM Coaching, Mentoring, and Networking Opportunities; 3) Exposure to Prestigious Minority Models in STEM and 4) Academic and Professional STEM Career Advancement Opportunities. This conference provided an environment for students to lean into their scientific advancement as the world continued to rebuild after COVID-19. Highlights included a session sponsored by GEM Grad Lab encouraged students to pursue graduate degrees and provided insight into the graduate school application process and funding opportunities. The National Science Foundation Division of Industrial Innovation and Partnerships (IIP) in the Engineering Directorate leads several programs to translate fundamental research into market solutions. During the conference, they offered an Innovation Tank where several top executives and NSF program managers gave valuable feedback to presenters who offered ideas and new methods.  Additionally, NSF presented a session central role in accelerating the growth of the national ecosystem and explored specific funding opportunities available to researchers, budding entrepreneurs, and innovators. Students received free resume reviews, networking tips, and an opportunity to engage with the 64 exhibitors. The Percy L. Julian Award recipient was Dr. Dorothy J. Wingfield Phillips, who discussed her chemical research career and life story. Several students received offers of internships and received interviews at the conference.

An evaluation of the student attendees indicated that the conference enhanced their identity as scientists and engineers. On average, participants’ sense of belonging to the NOBCChE community is influenced by a shared emotional connection to the community, reinforcement of needs, and the overall influence of the NOBCChE community. While the 49th Annual Conference was held amidst forecasts projecting a hurricane, which eventually made landfall in Orlando toward the end of the conference, attendees expressed that the way the leadership handled the situation fostered a greater sense of community. Complimenting technical talks, presentations and poster sessions were networking events to facilitate networking and increase community among the NOBCChE conference attendees. Participants described a “welcoming”, “supportive” and inclusive environment that embraced people from various backgrounds and ethnicities, which facilitated making personal connections to presenters and conference organizers.

These results indicate that the NOBCChE conference provides an environment that supports the intellectual and emotional development of underrepresented students as they transition through their academic programs. This support system is vital to increasing student’s sense of belonging and long-term retention in chemistry and chemical engineering.

 


Last Modified: 01/20/2024
Modified by: Tyrslai M Williams-Carter
